data.meta_description:
256 likes, 4 comments - galeriecanesso on June 4, 2024: "Reflecting on 2015, when we published the gallery catalogue ‘Alessandro Magnasco (1667-1749). Les années de la maturité d’un peintre anticonformiste,’ the title underscores Magnasco’s unique body of work.

His ‘Soldiers and Beggars’ features Nordic iconography, inspired by the Flemish Guard Corps and the German and Dutch soldier and vagrant scenes from the sixteenth century, likely familiar to Magnasco through Genoese and Medicean collections in Florence. He also drew from Spanish picaresque novels and Italian beggar literature, such as Croce’s La Strazzosa et molta meschina Compagnia del Mantellaccio (1600) and La Tremenda e spaventevole compagnia di tagliacantoni overo scapigliati (1614).

The characters in his work resemble the pícaros of Alemán and Quevedo, or Grimmelshausen’s mercenaries in Simplicissimus (1668). These vagabonds, driven by war and famine, represent a non-conformist reality, contrasting with the noble subjects of traditional literature and decorative painting. Magnasco’s scenes of pícaros and beggars feature protagonists emerging from dark backgrounds, with fragmented brushstrokes and luminous highlights, a style he explored throughout his life.

Galerie Canesso, celebrating 30 years, features this painting in its anniversary exhibition in Paris, previously showcased in collaboration with the @MuseidiStradaNuovaGenova. Visit us in Paris or Milan to delve into our history and share new perspectives. We look forward to welcoming you!
